Award.AwardTitle: CPS/Synergy/Collaborative Research: Smart Calibration Through Deep Learning for High-Confidence and Interoperable Cyber-Physical Additive Manufacturing Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive Manufacturing holds the promise of revolutionizing manufacturing. One important trend is the emergence of cyber additive manufacturing communities for innovative design and fabrication. However, due to variations in materials and processes, design and computational algorithms currently have limited adaptability and scalability across different additive manufacturing systems. This award will establish the scientific foundation and engineering principles needed to achieve adaptability, extensibility, and system scalability in cyber-physical additive manufacturing systems, resulting in high efficiency and accuracy fabrication. The research will facilitate the evolution of existing isolated and loosely-connected additive manufacturing facilities into fully functioning cyber-physical additive manufacturing systems with increased capabilities. The application-based, smart interfacing infrastructure will complement existing cyber additive communities and enhance partnerships between academia, industry, and the general public. The research will contribute to the technology and engineering of Cyber-physical Systems and the economic competitiveness of US manufacturing. This interdisciplinary research will generate new curricular materials and help educate a new generation of cybermanufacturing workforce.

The research will establish smart and dynamic system calibration methods and algorithms through deep learning that will enable high-confidence and interoperable cyber-physical additive manufacturing systems. The dynamic calibration and re-calibration algorithms will provide a smart interfacing layer of infrastructure between design models and physical additive manufacturing systems. Specific research tasks include: (1) Establishing smart and fast calibration algorithms to make physical additive manufacturing machines adaptable to design models; (2) Deriving prescriptive compensation algorithms to achieve extensible design models; (3) Dynamic recalibration through deep learning for improved predictive modeling and compensation; and (4) Developing a smart calibration server and APP prototype test bed for scalable additive cyberinfractures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Manufacturing has become increasingly hyper-connected and accessible with the advancement of the industrial Internet of Things, and Cyber-Physical Systems as its backbone. Cybermanufacturing has been proposed as a future manufacturing paradigm with seamless integration of computing, manufacturing, and services. A new class of cybermanufacturing technologies with significant potential to fundamentally transform how people interact with manufacturing is the cyber-physical additive manufacturing system (CPAMS). The individual processes in such a system manufacture products from computer-aided design models by adding material layer by layer, enabling the direct fabrication of complex shapes and eliminating the bulk and waste associated with traditional manufacturing. The advantages offered by CPAMS can potentially inaugurate a revolutionary new era in manufacturing.

The revolutionary potential impact of CPAMS was previously limited due to three critical issues. First is the need for adaptability to CAD models in the CPAMS to reliably manufacture high-quality products. Second is the fact that CPAMS target low volume, personalized manufacturing of complex products with frequent design changes, and that the existing library of design models and associated computational algorithms must be extensible in a manner such that newly designed products can be fabricated with high fidelity in a CPAMS. Third is that although individual machines in a CPAMS are primarily limited to low volume production, a CPAMS has the potential to mobilize all machines in the distributed system to achieve higher volume manufacturing, and the performance of the CPAMS measured by yield and quality should not deteriorate for a scaled-up CPAMS system. These issues lead to the following important question, which was the focus of this project: how can we establish a smart, interfacing layer of infrastructure with computational algorithms for CPAMS to catalyze their existing cyberinfrastructures into fully functioning CPAMS?

Our joint collaborative research with the University of Southern California has provided a framework, and associated statistical methodology and machine learning algorithms, for the dynamic and efficient calibration and recalibration of CPAMS. The framework was formulated using a computationally efficient and adaptive neural network algorithm and a statistical framework involving modular deviation features for products manufactured using CPAMS. This framework has three components: (a) formulating a discrepancy measure that captures the deviation features that are unique to new shapes, (b) modeling the inferred deviation features based on a small sample of manufactured test products, and (c) incorporating newly learned deviation features with previous deviation models. The framework and methodology/algorithms established by our research team enable straightforward and efficient recalibration of CPAMS. Furthermore, our framework enables the derivation of physical insights on the inferred relationships between individual or pairs of inputs and shape deviations. These facts were demonstrated by a large number of case studies for in-plane and out-of-plane shape deviation modeling across a wide variety of geometries.

Ultimately, the results of our research from studies on a large amount of CPAMS data indicate that the outcomes of this project can advance comprehensive quality control for CPAMS, and consequently contribute to smarter CPAMS.

There have been extensive and productive collaborations among the PIs from Purdue and the University of Southern California. The project provided opportunities for interdisciplinary training of PhD students due to the collaborative research among the PIs. One doctoral student, who received her PhD in Statistics from Purdue in May 2019, benefited from this project, in that she wrote three papers (which formed her dissertation) motivated by this project. The research outcomes have been disseminated nationally. Specifically, manuscripts describing our framework, statistical methodology, and machine learning algorithms, and containing real-life case studies, have been published in Technometrics, IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering, the Proceedings of the Twelfth Annual IEEE International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering (CASE 2016), and the Proceedings of the AHFE 2019 International Conference on Additive Manufacturing, Modeling Systems and 3D Prototyping. The latter manuscript has been recognized as a winner of the AHFE 2019 Best Paper Award. The results of this research have been presented at multiple conferences, workshops, and seminar series. A beta version of an application programming interface (API) that facilitates the implementation of our deviation modeling methodology for CPAMS was developed in 2020. A patent application for the automated deviation modeling computer algorithm and app developed in this project was submitted in 2019.
